{{Jews and Judaism sidebar}} An '''independent minyan''' is a lay-led [[Judaism|Jewish]] worship and study community that has developed independently of established denominational and synagogue structures within the organized Jewish community. Some began in the late 1990s and most since the year 2000,[http://allianceforcre.org/acre-conferences/20089-acre-conference/conference-summary/independent-minyanim Speech by Elie Kaunfer, Nov. 9, 2009, at the Alliance for Continuing Rabbinic Education (ACRE).] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110524001620/http://allianceforcre.org/acre-conferences/20089-acre-conference/conference-summary/independent-minyanim |date=2011-05-24 }} though some are several decades older.http://www.newtoncentreminyan.org/ These new groups often combine a commitment to [[halakha]]/Jewish law with [[egalitarianism]], and strive to create worship services where traditional prayer can become "spiritual experiences." The name, [[minyan]], comes from the [[Hebrew language|Hebrew]] word ('''מנין''') for the prayer quorum traditionally required for a full Jewish prayer service. ==Independent minyan phenomenon== [[File:DCMinyan Hanukkah.JPG|thumb|right|300px|Members of the [[DC Minyan]] light candles in celebration of the Festival of [[Hanukkah]].]] Scholars of religion are looking very closely at the development of these lay-led congregations, most of which are held in locations other than synagogues, although some use synagogue space while maintaining separate leadership and organizational structures. Some synagogue and Jewish community leaders take a negative position on this development, seeing the new groups as a threat to conventional synagogue and Jewish community organization.[https://www.nytimes.com/2007/11/28/us/28minyan.html?_r=1 "Challenging Tradition, Young Jews Worship on Their Terms," New York Times, Nov 28, 2007.] On the other hand, there are those who view the trend as extremely positive, and one that will ultimately lead to new approaches to religion and spirituality within the modern Jewish community: a "triumphant story of day-school education and egalitarianism."[http://www.jewishideasdaily.com/content/detail/continue-reading-a-minyan-grows-in-washington-dc Jack Wertheimer, "Vital Signs: A Minyan Grows in Washington, D.C.," ''Jewish Ideas Daily,'' April 29, 2010.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100503174411/http://www.jewishideasdaily.com/content/detail/continue-reading-a-minyan-grows-in-washington-dc |date=May 3, 2010 }} [[Jack Wertheimer]], a Professor of Jewish History at the [[Jewish Theological Seminary of America]] has written that: {{quote|For some who take a longer view, the independent minyanim seem reminiscent of the [[Chavurah|Havurah movement]] of the 1970s, when numbers of young American Jews rejected the suburban synagogues of their parents in favor of small-group gatherings for study, prayer, and community. Commenting on the parallels between then and now, the scholar Riv-Ellen Prell has also underscored the differences. One salient difference is today's higher level of Jewish and Hebrew fluency, itself a testament to the organized community's investment in intensive Jewish education over the past two decades. The historical moment is also different; members of today's independent minyanim are not counter-cultural types in rebellion against their parents or committed to smashing existing institutions but a generation that is at once self-sufficient and open to compromise. An example of the newer spirit is the DC Minyan's commitment to separate seating, an infringement on the principle of strict sexual egalitarianism that is maintained for the sake of accommodating the group's diverse population. In the present moment, pluralism is valued over purity.}} ==Nomenclature== Some sources refer to the "independent minyan movement", drawing a parallel between the increasing number of independent minyanim and the past creation of established Jewish denominations (known as "movements"). Others reject the "movement" terminology and refer instead to the "independent minyan phenomenon" or simply to "independent minyanim" without a collective noun, because independent minyanim are not affiliated with a set of central organizations, and do not share a religious ideology.''Jewschool'', December 14, 2008, [http://jewschool.com/2008/12/14/14341/independent-minyan-conference-closing-plenary/ "Independent Minyan Conference closing plenary"] Others still refer to the "independent minyan movement", understanding "movement" not in the sense of [[Jewish religious movements]], but in the sense of [[social movement]]s (such as the [[civil rights movement]], or more closely parallel, the [[havurah]] movement); or a community/cultural movement, such as the [[Jewish Community Center]] movement.[{{cite web |url=http://www.jcca.org/about_us.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-01-06 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110104074527/http://www.jcca.org/about_us.html |archivedate=2011-01-04 |df= }} "About JCC Association," which includes a description of the "JCC Movement" dating back to 1854, with the opening of the first [[Young Men's Hebrew Association]]. Others reject this sense of "movement" as well, because the connotation of "movement" among some members of the American Jewish community is too strongly related to its use regarding "denominations" (a fact that has led to confusion in the case of the havurah movement), and because independent minyanim arise for a number of different reasons, so that not all can be attributed to the same "movement". Some (see "2007 Spiritual Communities Study," below) have argued for incorporating the independent minyan model as a subcategory of a broader "Jewish Emergent" phenomenon (named after a parallel movement in the Christian church). "Jewish emergent" encompasses both the independent minyan movement"Turned off by Traditional Services, Young Jews Form New Prayer Groups." Jewish Telegraphic Agency, September 12, 2006. and so-called "rabbi-led emergent" communities, such as [[IKAR (Jewish congregation)|IKAR]] and [[Kavana Cooperative|Kavana]]. ==Characteristics== Rabbi [[Elie Kaunfer]], executive director of [[Yeshivat Hadar|Mechon Hadar]] and a [[rosh yeshiva]] (Rabbinic dean) of Yeshivat Hadar has defined today's "independent minyan" as a congregation meeting three requirements: (1) volunteer-led and organized with no paid clergy; (2) no denomination/movement affiliation; and (3) founded in the past 10 years. Kaunfer adds the goal of "spiritual prayer" to this list, noting that he himself often experienced worship services more as a "community experience" than as a "spiritual one."[http://www.thejewishweek.com/arts/books/get_serious_about_your_jewish_life_interview_elie_kaunfer "Get Serious About Your Jewish Life: An Interview with Elie Kaunfer," The New York Jewish Week, April 7, 2010.] Kaunfer notes that [[Kehilat Hadar]] began in New York as a result of a number of young Jews who were "looking for new ways to connect to the substance of their religion and tradition"—but instead of becoming "just a local minyan," "it became a model of grassroots religious community that spread dramatically across the United States and Israel. That model of community came to be known as an "independent minyan." An article on [[Kol Zimrah]], another independent minyan on New York's Upper West Side, called many of the new independent minyans "part of what some have called a Jewish spiritual renaissance, with its emphasis on personal spirituality and connection with the divine." [http://www.forward.com/articles/7093 Jay Michaelson, "A Prayer Group of Their Own: Kol Zimrah and Other Do-It-Yourself Minyans Unite the Independent Minded," The Forward, Nov 14, 2003.] Kaunfer emphasizes that the word "independent" means that many of these groups developed independently in terms of volunteers coming together to create and lead it, but—in agreement with Wertheimer's assessment of these minyanim—they are not nor do they seek to be independent of the larger Jewish community in terms of their vision or self-identity. "Quite the contrary," he says, "they see themselves filling a need not being met by existing institutions, but operating within the larger Jewish map, not outside or against it." In his view, the phenomenon represented by the increasingly large number of independent minyans (Hebrew: minyanim) on both the national and international scene carries an important message for Jewish community leaders:
Among American Jews, there is a significant demand for meaningful, engaged Jewish life. There is a temptation to assume that Jews – especially young adults – are only interested in surface level engagement with Jewish culture: jokes, bagels, singles events. Anything challenging, deep or smacking of religion might scare people away. This is simply not the case. Jews are in search of meaning and engagement, and they are interested in the wisdom of their own heritage. They may not find that engagement in existing institutions, but that does not mean they aren't looking for it. They are looking for more than a class; they want to build real community. They want substance, and they want the skills to own their Jewish lives.
Experts like [[Jonathan Sarna]], professor of American Jewish history at Brandeis University, agree, noting that the values that participants are bringing to these groups can add a new vision to the community:
It is an interesting mix between the egalitarian, pluralistic, inclusive values coming from the left and the values of learning and of observance coming from the right. They are making a new synthesis of these traditional and modern values that we haven't seen before.[http://www.spokesman.com/stories/2009/jun/06/new-judaism Jackquelin L. Salmon, "New Judaism," ''Washington Post'', June 6, 2009.]
Ari Kelman, a professor of American studies at the University of California at Davis, predicts that, "They are going to have a huge impact, because we are living in a moment where denominations are really not very successful, particularly with these 20- and 30-somethings." ===2007 Spiritual Communities Study=== In 2007, [[Hebrew Union College]] [[sociologist]] [http://huc.edu/faculty/faculty/SteveCohen.shtml Steven Cohen] conducted a survey on behalf of the S3K Synagogue Studies Institute and Mechon Hadar.[http://www.minyannaaleh.org/uploads/1/7/7/2/1772619/jta-11-30-07.pdf Sue Fishkoff, "First Study of Independent minyans: Young Jews Praying on Own Terms," JTA, Nov 30, 2007.] Based on 1354 responses to an [http://www.jewishemergent.org/survey/documents/NatSpirComStudy_SurveyInstrument.pdf online questionnaire], the study, co-authored by [[Shawn Landres]], Elie Kaunfer, and Michelle Shain, found that social networking, not institutional structures, was the primary way that information about independent minyans spread. Additional findings included the fact that participants that the majority of participants had some day school education, or experience in Jewish summer camps, or college organizations like Hillel; 40% grew up in the Conservative movement; most were unmarried, and under 40; one third were male, and two thirds female; and most were "comfortable in Hebrew." More than half of the respondents had spent more than four months in Israel. Additionally, most attended services at least once a month, and two thirds prayed with more than one congregation. In terms of affiliation with one of the religious movements within Judaism, the study found that: {{quote|Many minyan participants raised Orthodox or Conservative still identify as such, even if the minyan itself is not institutionally affiliated. But virtually all of those who were raised Reform no longer identify with that religious stream: Less than 3% of those involved with independent minyanim consider themselves Reform Jews.}} While the study's findings are subject to interpretation, it is clear that the majority of participants in independent minyanim have benefited from the institutions and programs of the organized Jewish community, but are now seeking to add something new:
You can see the growth of independent minyanim as proof of the failure, or of the success, of the established U.S. Jewish community's efforts to keep the next generation involved. Those efforts include the expansion of Jewish day schools, of the on-campus Hillel movement for Jewish students, and of programs in Israel for young Jews. Independent minyan members, much more than other American Jews, are alumni of all these programs. The 2007 study showed that over half had spent four months or more in Israel for a single visit -- far above the proportion for the wider Jewish community. Yet they haven't found their place in the established synagogues. They're likely to say they are "nondenominational" -- a term usually, and mistakenly, taken as meaning that someone is drifting away from Judaism. Instead, they've created a traditional Judaism with an anarchic accent, in which participants expect rabbis to teach them but not to lead their services or be religious in their place.[http://www.prospect.org/cs/articles?article=a_fresh_take_on_the_jewish_faith Gershom Goremberg, "A Fresh Take on the Jewish Faith: A new community of American Judaism is embracing religious traditionalism and social liberalism," The American Prospect, March 12, 2010.]
It is also clear that participants in the minyans support the idea of Jewish community, in the United States and abroad, but think for themselves. So, for example, the study showed that the majority felt "very emotionally attached to Israel," but only the minority answered yes to the question of whether they are "always" proud of Israel. ==Tradition and egalitarianism== [[File:Tikkun Leil Purim.jpg|thumb|left|300px|Members of independent minyan [[Tikkun Leil Shabbat]] celebrate the Jewish holiday of [[Purim]]]] Many independent minyanim seek approaches within traditional Jewish law as foundation for egalitarianism, and an expanded role of women both in the worship service and in the leadership structure. Jerusalem's Kehilat Shira Hadasha is credited as being the first Jewish congregation to implement an opinion by [[Modern Orthodox]] Rabbi [[Mendel Shapiro]], whose writing, [http://www.edah.org/backend/JournalArticle/1_2_shapiro.pdf "Qeri’at ha-Torah by Women: A Halakhic Analysis"],Mendel Shapiro, [http://www.edah.org/backend/JournalArticle/1_2_shapiro.pdf "Qeri’at ha-Torah by Women: A Halakhic Analysis," Edah 1:2, 2001.] cites and explains some precedents for allowing women to read from the Torah. (Some minyanim, like the [http://leader-minyan.helping.org.il Leader Minyan], also in Jerusalem, had a similar practice since the 1990s, before Rabbi Shapiro's opinion was released.) Another Modern Orthodox rabbi whose writings are frequently cited by minyanim like Shira Hadasha is [[Daniel Sperber]]. Like Shapiro, Sperber argues in [http://www.edah.org/backend/JournalArticle/3_2_Sperber.pdf "Congregational Dignity and Human Dignity: Women and Public Torah Reading"] that many past opinions recognized that there was religious legal support for the increased participation of women, but that this participation was not allowed because it was considered in societal/sociologial terms to be an "affront to the congregation" (Hebrew: kevod ha-tsibur). Based on changes in society—at least within the context of the communities that make up some specific minyanim—rabbis like Shapiro and Sperber support such participation as no longer being an affront to the participants. Furthermore, Sperber argues that human dignity (Hebrew: kevod ha beriyot) should be recognized as the value that should drive changes in the participation of women in services.The Edah Journal, 1:2, 2001. While the positions of rabbis like Shapiro and Sperber have been criticized by some others, Shapiro responds that, "Among Jews there have been disputes throughout all the generations."[http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-3262945,00.html Neta Sela, "Battle Over Women's Rights to Pray: Jerusalem Synagogue 'Shira Hadasha' Stirs Controversy After Permitting Women to Join Minyan," Israel Jewish Scene, June 14, 2006.] Rabbi Shapiro, who himself prays at Shira Hadasha, adds, "This is a synagogue where the congregants are people who are interested in religious development. We don't want to harm anyone, and we don't want others to harm us." In addition to its early use of opinions like those of Shapiro and Sperber, Shira Hadasha is also generally recognized as the first independent minyan to come up with the hybrid of tradition and egalitarianism that adds to the prayer quorum requirement of ten men the additional requirement of ten women.[http://www.shirahadasha.com/Shira_Hadasha/Reading.html Shira Hadasha website.] Today, many other independent minyanim follow this approach, as well.[http://judaism.about.com/od/feminism/a/shirahadasha.htm Shira Hadasha, About.com.] For example, the Australian congregation Shira Melbourne notes on its website that it is "modeled on the Shira Hadasha community in Jerusalem."[http://www.shira.org.au/about Shira Melbourne website.] One [[Los Angeles]] minyan, which also notes that it is "modeled after Shira Hadasha in Jerusalem," takes its name from this practice, calling itself the "Ten and Ten Minyan."[https://groups.yahoo.com/group/10and10-Minyan Ten and Ten Minyan.] Some other minyanim, like [[MigdalOr]] admit that they "struggle" with the concept, but sometimes find it impractical to implement.[[Migdalor#"Ten and Ten" policy|MigdalOr article, "Ten and Ten policy" section.]] Though independent minyanim indeed operate independently and share no formal "movement" structure, there are strong informal links between these communities in different cities. Thus, many groups cite others as models, learning from and even modeling themselves after others:
The founders of these independent minyans have all learned from one another. Indeed, most know each other through networks such as the [http://www.college.columbia.edu/students/fellowships/catalog/dorot-fellowship Dorot Fellowship’s] alumni organization and have shared ideas and inspiration. D.C. Minyan founder Jessica Lieberman explicitly took Hadar as a model. Tiferet founder Evan Hochberg said he and his co-founders "were inspired by Darchei Noam and by Shira Hadasha in Jerusalem. We wanted to create a safe space for people to be Orthodox and [[feminism|feminist]] at the same time."
Ultimately, the leaders of many of these groups see the commitment to tradition on the one hand, and to egalitarianism (or feminism) on the other, as the "core values" of the vision that gives their communities foundation—although individual participants and individual congregations take different positions on exactly "how these values should intersect." For example, the website for [http://www.minyannaaleh.org Minyan Na'aleh] in [[Denver]], [[Colorado]], explains:
At Minyan Na'aleh, you can expect a traditional and complete davening that is conducted mainly in Hebrew. We are completely lay-led and have no official Rabbi or affiliation with a particular movement. Our Friday night service is completely egalitarian, with men and women seated together, while Shabbat morning and some of our other services (Shavuot and Kol Nidrei ) are conducted in an Orthodox egalitarian style (women lead some, but not all, parts of the service and seating is separated by gender). Why do we conduct services differently at different times? Because adherence to tradition and egalitarianism are core values for us, and because members of our community have differing opinions about how these values should intersect.[http://www.minyannaaleh.org/what-to-expect.html Minyan Na'aleh: "What to Expect."]
An article about Minyan Shivyoni, in the [[Baka, Jerusalem|Baka]] area of Jerusalem, describes how the resolution of these "differing opinions" often results in a process of struggle among participants that is not easy, but the goal is "communal consensus":
As the Minyan Shivyoni navigates the process of becoming more egalitarian, each decision begins with open communal learning on the topic of discussion. From that point, there is an e-mail follow-up, disseminating the traditional sources discussed, which lead to more ideological and value-driven missives. Then, there is a vote. "There is a shared culture and atmosphere, even though there are great gaps between the different people in the minyan," [Co-founder Yair] Furstenburg said. "People give different weight to different elements—values, custom, traditional legal texts, atmosphere."[http://www.presentense.org/magazine/minyans-of-the-people "Minyans of the People: The Rise of Lay-Led Congregations," Present Tense, August 21, 2009.]
One new term being used to describe the synthesis of traditional Jewish law and equal participation by men and women is "halakhic egalitarian."[http://www.cambridgeminyan.org/pages/mission.htm Cambridge Minyan website: "Mission."] In addition to "core values" such as halakha and egalitarianism, some congregations, like [http://www.darcheinoam.org.il Darchei Noam, in [[Modiin]], Israel,] add a "commitment to social justice," as well—a concept that many participants believe includes egalitarianism, but is not limited to it.[http://www.darcheinoam.org.il/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=1:welcome&catid=1:darchei&lang=en&Itemid= Darchei Noam website: Orthodox Egalitarian Community in Modiin.] ==The Minyan Project== Within the overall rubric of the independent minyan phenomenon described by experts like Wertheimer, Kaunfer, Sarna, Kelman, and others who are studying it, many independent minyanim work as active participants in [http://www.mechonhadar.org/minyan-project The Minyan Project], an international effort to support lay-led congregations, under the leadership of New York's Mechon Hadar, an institution that developed as a result of the growth of Kehilat Hadar. It is "designed to empower vibrant prayer communities," offering one-on-one consulting, including resources and strategic planning advice, to leaders of groups around the county. In addition, it offers both on-line and traditional classes and courses. In November 2008, it facilitated a three-day leadership conference for over 90 representatives from 32 communities to create a system of networking and mutual support, in an effort to share best practices, lessons learned, and define ongoing and upcoming issues. It also held a one-day public forum at [[Brandeis University]] that attracted 120 representatives from conventional Jewish institutions, and included a keynote address in addition to eight panel discussions, involving scholars, Jewish professionals, and community worship leaders. Mechon Hadar organized another conference in April 2010 which included sessions on such issues as "Building a Singing Community," "expanding the concept" of egalitarianism, the "theory and practice" of pluralism, "empowering" existing communities, and the challenges and rewards of holding simultaneous multiple worship services within a synagogue setting.[http://www.mechonhadar.org/minyan-project1 ''Mechon Hadar'' website, ''Minyan Project'' section] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100514153121/http://www.mechonhadar.org/minyan-project1 |date=2010-05-14 }} As part of this ongoing effort, the Minyan Project has developed a "Halakhic Think Tank" to provide a forum for discussion and guidance on "crucial halakhic issues facing ... burgeoning communities, including gender, kashrut, defining relationships and boundaries with the non-Jewish world ... [and] navigating different levels of observance with the Jewish community." ==Partnership minyanim== {{main|Partnership minyan}} {{main|Guide for the Halakhic Minyan}} While many independent minyanim do not identify with any one of the [[Jewish religious movements]], [[Partnership minyan]] is a term being used by the [[Jewish Orthodox Feminist Alliance]] (JOFA) to describe those that seek to expand the leadership role of women while still identifying themselves as part of the [[Modern Orthodox]] community, within the overall rubric of [[Orthodox Judaism]]. In 2008, members of JOFA approached two PhD candidates in [[New England]] who were working as consultants to a number of minyanim, with the recommendation that a guide be created to help groups such as Partnership minyanim. [http://www.ynet.co.il/english/articles/0,7340,L-3505012,00.html "New Guide for the Halachic and Egalitarian, Ynet.news, Oct 2, 2008.] In 2008, the [https://web.archive.org/web/20110714100817/http://minyanurim.com/uploads/Guideline%20for%20Halachic%20Minyanim%20January%2019%20-%20English.pdf "Guide for the 'Halakhic Minyan.'"] was published. The guide is meant to help minyanim seeking halakhic justification for expansion of women in leadership roles in different areas of the service and in different ways, whether or not complete egalitarianism, equal roles, is part of the minyan's self-described vision or goals: "While many ... minyanim aim to extend participation to women as far as Halacha permits, they are by no means egalitarian - hence the phrase 'halachic minyan' in the title of the guide, and not 'egalitarian minyan.'"[http://www.jpost.com/JewishWorld/JewishNews/Article.aspx?id=92578 "First Guide for Inclusive Prayer Services is Published," ''[[Jerusalem Post]]'', Feb 19, 2008.] ==See also== *[http://www.thejewisheye.com/ek_empower.html Book Review: "Empowered Judaism: How Independent Minyanim Can Teach Us about Building Vibrant Jewish Communities," by Rabbi Elie Kaunfer.] *[http://www.shirahadasha.com/Shira_Hadasha/Reading.html List of additional readings, some with internet links to texts.] *[http://www.jofa.org/social.php/orthodoxy/feminismandh List and brief description of books and articles on Judaism, halakha, and feminism, on website of Jewish Orthodox Feminist Alliance (JOFA).] *[http://www.synagogue3000.org/working-group-emergent-sacred-communities-0 Synagogue3000: Working Group on Emergent Sacred Communities.] *[http://www.edah.org/backend/JournalArticle/sperber_5_2_final.pdf Daniel Sperber, "''Friendly'' Halakha and the ''Friendly'' Posek," The Edah Journal 5:2, 2006: an article arguing that contemporary rabbis and halakhic decisors should reexamine the manner they employ to make religious decisions.] *[[Aryeh Frimer]], [http://www.daat.ac.il/daat/english/tfila/frimer2-1.htm "Women and Minyan," Tradition 23:4, pp54-77, Summer 1988.] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20110111155609/http://www.mechonhadar.org/c/document_library/get_file?uuid=8e2def5c-17b6-4160-9fe3-874c9c9c3587&groupId=11401 "Egalitarianism, Tefillah, and Halakhah."] (Produced as a result of a project coordinated by Open Source:A Halakhah Think Tank, www.halakhah.org.) ==References== ==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20110716055847/http://www.shirahadasha.com/Shira_Hadasha/Minyanim_Worldwide.html Partial information list on independent minyanim worldwide.] *[https://docs.google.com/spreadsheet/ccc?key=0AqVEvVxI0Q8LdF81YjRiaDNuWXM3Vzl2aFBQUGtQX2c#gid=0 Google doc table of independent minyanim] which can be updated [https://docs.google.com/spreadsheet/viewform?formkey=dFkzX2dYcUtEY041N2htNUUyOG1kMUE6MQ#gid=0 here] *[http://www.jewishemergent.org/survey/documents/NatSpirComStudy_HomepageCompendium.pdf Compilation of information on independent minyans in the U.S.] *[http://www.mechonhadar.org/web/guest/minyan-conferences Recordings of selected sessions at ''Minyan Project'' conferences.] *[https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2009/04/28/AR2009042803584.html "Synthesis Outside the Synagogue," The Washington Post, April 29, 2009.] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20100920165734/http://dcminyan.org/inTheNews/wjw-03-03-2005.html "An Orthodox blossoming In District, traditional offerings grow, as do names," The Washington Jewish Week, March 3, 2005.] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20100920165516/http://dcminyan.org/inTheNews/forward08-10-01.html "Any Old Shul Won't Do for the Young and Cool: Post-Boomers Have It Their Way at Spate of New Prayer Groups," April 10, 2001.] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20100610114737/http://www.jta.org/news/article/2008/11/11/1000894/minyanim-growing "Independent Minyanim Growing Rapidly, and the Jewish World is Noticing," JTA, Nov 11, 2008.] *[http://www.tabletmag.com/life-and-religion/26047/minyin-man "Minyan Man," Tablet, Feb 19, 2010.] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20110713104000/http://jewishvoiceandopinion.com/pdf/200707.pdf#page=8 "Partnership Minyanim: Orthodoxy on the Edge (Or Maybe Even a Little Bit Over)," Jewish Voice and {{cleanup|reason=Wording is loose and unclear, not up to encyclopedic standards|date=October 2018}} {{Infobox saint |name= Saint James Intercisus |birth_date= |death_date=421 |feast_day= November 27 |venerated_in= [[Eastern Orthodox Church]]
[[Roman Catholic Church]]
[[Eastern Catholic Churches]]
[[Oriental Orthodoxy]] |image= James Intercisus.jpg |imagesize= 150px |caption= |birth_place=Persia |death_place=Persia |titles= |beatified_date= |beatified_place= |beatified_by= |canonized_date= |canonized_place= |canonized_by= |attributes= |patronage= |major_shrine= |suppressed_date= |issues= }} [[file:James the Persian (Menologion of Basil II).jpg|thumb]] '''Saint James Intercisus''', also known as '''Saint James the Mutilated''' (died 421) was a [[Persian people|Persian]] Christian [[saint]]. His [[surname]], ''Intercisus'', is derived from the [[Latin]] word for "cut into pieces," which refers to the manner of his [[martyrdom]]: he was slowly [[Lingchi|cut into twenty-eight pieces]]. He survived this loss of limbs before being ultimately [[decapitation|beheaded]]. Tradition states that he was a military officer and [[courtier]] to [[Yazdegerd I]] who had [[apostasy|apostatized]] after this ruler began to persecute Christians. Under the influence of his Christian family, however, he expressed his faith to Yazdegerd's successor, [[Bahram V]], and was tortured and killed.John J. Delaney, ''Dictionary of saints'', (Image, 2005), 323. His death started the [[Roman-Sassanid War (421-422)]]. He was killed in [[Gundishapur]]. The ruins of this city are near [[Dezful]], [[Iran]]. Somehow, his body was sent to the Portuguese cathedral of [[Braga]] and put into a sarcophagus in the Relics Chapel. James' story is recounted in ''[[The Golden Legend]]''. The [[Church of St. James Intercisus]] in the [[Armenian Quarter]] of [[Jerusalem]] is dedicated to him.Adrian J. Boas, ''Jerusalem in the time of the Crusades'', (Routledge, 2001), 128. The [[Monastery of St. Jacob Persian]] in Sireţi, [[Străşeni]] [[Moldova]], the [[Monastery of St. Jacob Persian]] in Deddeh, [[Lebanon]] and the [[Monastery of Saint James the Mutilated (Qara)|monastery of St James the Mutilated]] in Qara, Syria are all dedicated to him. His feast day is November 27. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *{{it icon}} [http://www.santiebeati.it/dettaglio/91626 San Giacomo l'Interciso (il Solitario) Martire in Persia] *The Holy Martyr James the Persian [http://www.holycross-hermitage.com/pages/Orthodox_Life/st_james_persian.htm] *{{ro icon}} [http://manastirea-sireti.md/ Monastery of St. Jacob Persian] == Bibliography == *Thieleman J. van Braght, ''Martyr's Mirror'', 1660 {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Intercisus, James}} [[Category:Persian saints]] [[Category:421 deaths]] [[Category:5th-century Christian saints]] [[Category:5th-century Iranian people]] [[Category:Year of birth unknown]] [[Category:People executed by the Sasanian Empire]] [[Category:Christians in the Sasanian Empire]] [[Category:Portuguese Roman Catholic saints]] [[Category:Converts to Zoroastrianism from Christianity]] [[Category:Converts to Christianity from Zoroastrianism]]

{{Infobox person | name = Joseph Bau | image = יוסף באו...jpg | caption = Joseph Bau | native_name = יוסף באו | birth_date = {{Birth date|1920|6|13}} | birth_place = [[Kraków]], [[Second_Polish_Republic|Poland]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|2002|5|24|1920|6|13}} | death_place = [[Tel Aviv]], [[Israel]] | nationality = Polish, Israeli | education = Jan Matejko Academy of Fine Arts
University of Plastic Arts | spouse = {{Marriage|Rebecca Tennenbaum|1943|1997|end=died}} | children = 2 }} [[File:Joseph Bau Museum in Tel Aviv.JPG|thumb|Joseph Bau museum in [[Tel Aviv]]]] '''Joseph Bau''' ({{lang-he|יוסף באו}}; 13 June 1920 – May 24 2002) was a [[Polish diaspora#Israel|Polish-Israeli]] artist, philosopher, inventor, animator, comedian, commercial creator, copy-writer, poet, and survivor of the [[Kraków-Płaszów concentration camp|Płaszów concentration camp]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/news/2002/jul/10/guardianobituaries.israel|title=Obituary: Joseph Bau|last=Joffe|first=Lawrence|date=10 July 2002|website=the Guardian|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-06-15}} == Life == Bau was trained as a graphic artist at the [[Jan Matejko Academy of Fine Arts]] in [[Kraków]], [[Poland]]. His education was interrupted by World War II and he was transferred to the [[Kraków-Płaszów concentration camp|Płaszów concentration camp]] in late 1942 from the [[Kraków Ghetto]]. Having a talent in gothic lettering, he was employed in the camp for making signs and maps for the [[Nazi Germany|Germans]]. While in Płaszów, Bau created a miniature - the size of his hand – illustrated book with his own poetry. He also forged documents and identity papers for people who managed to escape from the camp.{{Cite news|url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1998-11-03/news/9811030137_1_joseph-bau-holocaust-survivor-concentration-camp|title=Artist's Work Defies The Horror|last=Ko|first=Michael|date=3 November 1998|work=The Chicago Tribune|access-date=2018-08-26|language=en}} During his imprisonment, Bau fell in love with another inmate, Rebecca Tennenbaum. They were secretly married, despite the prohibition by the Germans, in the women's barracks of Płaszów. This was dramatized in [[Steven Spielberg]]'s [[Academy Award]]-winning movie ''[[Schindler's List]]'', where he was played by [[Rami Heuberger]]. Bau himself appears in the film's epilogue placing a stone on [[Oskar Schindler|Oskar Schindler's]] grave in [[Jerusalem]], along with his wife Rebecca.{{Cite news|url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2002-06-14/news/0206140210_1_joseph-bau-nazi-industrialist-oskar-schindler-clandestine-wedding|title=Joseph Bau, 81|last=|first=|date=June 14, 2002|work=The Chicago Tribune|access-date=2018-08-26|language=en}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/obituaries/1396465/Joseph-Bau.html|title=Joseph Bau|last=|first=|date=6 June 2002|work=The Daily Telegraph|access-date=2018-08-26|language=en-GB|issn=0307-1235}} After Płaszów, Bau was transferred to [[Gross-Rosen concentration camp]] and then to [[Brünnlitz labor camp|Schindler's camp]] where he stayed until the end of the war, while Rebecca was sent to [[Auschwitz concentration camp|Auschwitz]].{{Cite news|url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1993-12-19/news/9312190196_1_rebecca-tannenbaum-plaszow-schindler-jews|title=`Schindler' Couple Recall Terror|last=Hundley|first=Tom|date=19 December 1993|work=The Chicago Tribune|access-date=2018-08-26|language=en}} After liberation, Bau was reunited with his wife finished his degree at University of Plastic Arts in Kraków. In 1950, he immigrated to [[Israel]] together with his wife and three-year-old daughter, Hadassah, where their other daughter, Clila, was born. He worked as a graphic artist at the Brandwein Institute in [[Haifa]] and for the government of Israel. Bau opened his own studio in 1956 in [[Tel Aviv]], which is now a museum managed by daughters Hadassa and Clila. He was well known for creating graphic fonts and drawing titles for Israeli movies in the 1960s and 1970s. He also authored a number of [[Hebrew language|Hebrew]] books and continued to write poetry.{{Cite web|url=http://www.josephbau.com/?module=category&item_id=8|title=Joseph Bau|website=www.josephbau.com|access-date=2018-08-26}} Bau's wife Rebecca died in 1997. Bau died from [[pneumonia]] in [[Tel Aviv]] on May 24, 2002, at age 81.{{Cite news|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2002/jun/13/local/me-bau13|title=Joseph Bau, 81; Israeli Artist, Animator, Holocaust Survivor|last=McLellan|first=Dennis|date=2002-06-13|work=Los Angeles Times|access-date=2018-06-15|language=en-US|issn=0458-3035}} == Works == The English version of Joseph Bau's memoir, ''Dear God, Have You Ever Gone Hungry?'' came out in June 1998. It was first published in Hebrew and Polish and was published in several languages, including Chinese. Joseph Bau also created his own animated films, for which he has been referred to in the press as the "Israeli Walt Disney" or as the "founder of Israel's animation industry". His paintings and drawings have been listed by Sotheby's as significant contributions to the art of the Holocaust and his works have been shown in galleries in New York, Baltimore, Chicago, and Minneapolis. Joseph Bau's art is filtered through the prism of his own experiences. It reflects both the brutal reality of life during the war, as well as the joy and humour he observed in later years in Israel. Joseph Bau was nominated for the prestigious [[Israel Prize]] in 1998. ==References== == External links == *[http://www.josephbau.com Joseph Bau's Home Page] {{en icon}} * Giuseppe Sedia, [http://www.krakowpost.com/article/5785 ''Josef Bau: Israel’s Walt Disney and Mapmaker of Hell''], in [http://www.krakowpost.com The Krakow Post], 7 September 2012. {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Bau, Joseph}} [[Category:1920 births]] [[Category:2002 deaths]] [[Category:20th-century Israeli writers]] [[Category:Gross-Rosen concentration camp survivors]] [[Category:Israeli animators]] [[Category:Israeli illustrators]] [[Category:Israeli Jews]] [[Category:Israeli memoirists]] [[Category:Israeli poets]] [[Category:Jewish artists]] [[Category:Jewish Combat Organization members]] [[Category:Jewish Israeli artists]] [[Category:Jewish poets]] [[Category:Jewish resistance members during the Holocaust]] [[Category:Jewish writers]] [[Category:Kraków-Płaszów concentration camp survivors]] [[Category:Kraków Ghetto inmates]] [[Category:People from Kraków]] [[Category:Polish cartoonists]] [[Category:Polish emigrants to Israel]] [[Category:Polish Jews]] [[Category:Schindlerjuden]]

{{Infobox lake | name = Lake Iguaque | image = Panoramique iguaque 2011.jpg | caption = Lake Iguaque | pushpin_map = Colombia | image_bathymetry = | caption_bathymetry = | location = [[Villa de Leyva]], [[Boyacá Department|Boyacá]] | coords = {{coord|5.6879|-73.4366|type:waterbody_region:CO|format=dms|display=inline,title}} | type = | inflow = | outflow = | catchment = | basin_countries = Colombia | length = | width = | area = {{convert|6750|m2|abbr=on}} | depth = | max-depth = {{convert|5.2|m|abbr=on}} | volume = | residence_time = | shore = | elevation = {{convert|3800|m|abbr=on}} | islands = | cities = }} '''Lake Iguaque''' is a [[lake]] located in the [[Boyacá Department]] of [[Colombia]]. The lake and the surrounding area was declared a [[List of national parks of Colombia|Flora and Fauna Sanctuary]] in 1977.<ref>{{es}} {{cite web | url=http://www.parquesnacionales.gov.co/PNN/portel/libreria/php/decide.php?patron=01.022907 | title=Santuario de Fauna y Flora Iguaque | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6HEw84WMH?url=http://www.parquesnacionales.gov.co/PNN/portel/libreria/php/decide.php?patron=01.022907 | archivedate=2013-06-09 | df= }}</ref>
== Geography and climate== Lake Iguaque is located northeast of [[Villa de Leyva]] and is part of the SFF Iguaque. The predominant [[ecosystem]] is the [[páramo]], with presence of [[frailejón]] plant, [[fern]]s, [[lichen]]s and [[Puya (genus)|puya]]s. The average temperature is 12 °C. The route of access to the natural reservation is: [[Bogotá]] – [[Tunja]] (147 km) /Tunja – [[Villa de Leyva]] (39 km). The visitor center Furachiogua offers accommodation for up to 48 persons, and [[camping]] zone.<ref>{{es}} [http://www.ecomochilas.com/santuario-de-flora-y-fauna-de-iguaque/ Ecomochila - Lake Iquaque]</ref>
== Cultural value == Lake Iguaque was considered a sacred place for the [[Muisca people|Muisca]]. According to [[Muisca religion|legend]], mankind was originated in the Iguaque lake, when the goddess [[Bachué]] came out from the [[lake]] with a boy in her arms. When the boy grew, she married him and their children populated the Earth. They are considered the ancestors of the human race. Finally Bachué and her husband and son disappeared unto the lake in the shape of [[snake]]s.
== Biology == The in 2006 described [[Halictidae|sweat bee]] ''[[Neocorynura muiscae]]'' was found in the sanctuary near the lake and named after the Muisca.<ref>[https://journals.ku.edu/index.php/melittology/article/download/4812/4412.pdf ''Neocorynura muiscae'' found at an elevation of 2850 m]</ref>
== See also == {{Portal|Colombia}} *[[Muisca religion]], [[Bachué]] *[[Lake Guatavita]], [[Lake Tota]], [[Siecha Lakes]]

:''"Scottish abbey" redirects here. Not to be confused with [[Schottenstift, Vienna]].'' {{Use Scottish English|date=July 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2012}} '''List of monastic houses in Scotland''' is a catalogue of the [[abbey]]s, [[priory|priories]], [[friary|friaries]] and other monastic religious houses of Scotland. In this article [[alien house]]s are included, as are smaller establishments such as [[Monastic cell|cell]]s and notable [[monastic grange]]s (particularly those with resident monks). The numerous [[Hospitals in medieval Scotland|monastic hospital]]s ''per se'' are not included here unless at some time the foundation had, or was purported to have, the status or function of an abbey, priory, friary or [[preceptory]]/[[Commandery (feudalism)|commandery]]. The geographical co-ordinates provided are sourced from details provided by the [[Royal Commission on the Ancient and Historical Monuments in Scotland]] (RCAHMS)[http://www.rcahms.gov.uk/] and [[Ordnance Survey of Great Britain|Ordnance Survey]] publications. {{TOC right}} ==Overview== === Article layout === The list is presented alphabetically by [[council areas|council area]]. Foundations are listed alphabetically within each area. {{Scotland Regions Labelled Map|hash=#}} '''Communities/provenance''': shows the status and communities existing at each establishment, together with such dates as have been established as well as the fate of the establishment after [[Dissolution of the Monasteries|dissolution]], and the current status of the site. '''Formal name or dedication''': shows the formal name of the establishment or the person in whose name the church is dedicated, where known. '''Alternative names''': some of the establishments have had alternative names over the course of time. In order to assist in text-searching such alternatives in name or spelling have been provided. '''Monastic glossary''': following the listing, provides links to articles on the particular monastic orders as well as other terms which appear in the listing. ==Abbreviations and key== {| class="wikitable" |+ The sites listed are ruins unless indicated thus: |- ! * | indicates current monastic function |- ! + | indicates current non-monastic ecclesiastic function (including remains incorporated into later structure) |- ! ^ | indicates current non-ecclesiastic function (including remains incorporated into later structure) |- ! $ | indicates remains limited to earthworks etc. |- ! # | indicates no identifiable trace of the monastic foundation remains |- ! ~ | indicates exact site of monastic foundation unknown |} Locations with names in ''italics'' indicate probable duplication (misidentification with another location) or non-existent foundations (either erroneous reference or proposed foundation never implemented. | {|class="wikitable" |+ Trusteeship denoted as follows: |- |HES | [[Historic Environment Scotland]] |- | NTS | [[National Trust for Scotland]] |- |CS |[[Church of Scotland]] |} Communities/provenance: shows the status and communities existing at each establishment, together with such dates as have been established as well as the fate of the establishment after [[Dissolution of the Monasteries|dissolution]], and the current status of the site. Formal name or dedication: shows the formal name of the establishment or the person in whose name the church is dedicated, where known. Alternative names: some of the establishments have had alternative names over the course of time. In order to assist in text-searching such alternatives in name or spelling have been provided. == List of establishments by county/region == {{kml}} ===Aberdeen=== {|width=99% class="wikitable" !width = 15%|Foundation !width = 5%|Image !width = 30%|Communities & provenance !width = 20%|Formal name or dedication
& ''alternative names'' !width = 10%|Online references & location |- valign=top |Aberdeen Blackfriars | |'''Dominican Friars'''
''founded'' between 1230 and 1249, purportedly by [[Alexander II of Scotland|Alexander II]];
''destroyed'' by Reformers 4 January 1560;
secularised between 1560 and 1587; ''granted'' to George, Earl Marischal 17 May 1587;
site currently occupied by Robert Gordon's College, Schoolhill - see Parson Gordon's 1661 map showing "Blackfreers". |[[St John the Baptist]] | |- valign=top |Aberdeen Greyfriars | |'''Observant Franciscan Friars'''
''founded'' 1469;
secularised 29 December 1559; friars resigned entire possession over to the Town Council;
''granted'' to the Town Council by [[James VI and I|James VI]] 30 December 1567 for conversion into a hospital;
extant buildings passed to George, Earl Marischal 22 September 1593;
church became derelict until 1624;
''restored'' 1624 by the citizens; in parochial use until 1903 | |[http://canmore.rcahms.gov.uk/en/site/20146/details/aberdeen+greyfriars+church/ Site Record for Aberdeen, Greyfriars Church Marischal College; Grey Friar's Monastery; Aberdeen, Franciscan Friary Details]

{{coord|57.1494178|-2.0966506|format=dms|region:GB_type:landmark_source:enwiki|name=Aberdeen Greyfriars}} |- valign=top |Aberdeen Monastery | |'''Benedictine monks'''
supposed establishment;
''founded'' before 3 April 1231, when [[Pope Gregory IX|the Pope]] ''granted'' the use of the church of Culdedono to the abbot and convent 'de Aberdona' ;

{{Use dmy dates|date=May 2017}} {{Infobox UK legislation |short_title = Local Government (Religious etc. Observances) Act 2015 |type = Act |parliament = Parliament of the United Kingdom |long_title = An Act to make provision about the inclusion at local authority meetings of observances that are, and about powers of local authorities in relation to events that to any extent are, religious or related to a religious or philosophical belief. |year = 2015 |citation = 2015 c. 27 |introduced_by = [[Jake Berry]] ([[Private Member's Bill]]) |territorial_extent = [[England and Wales]] |si_made_date = |si_laid_date = |royal_assent = 26 March 2015 |commencement = 26 May 2015 |repeal_date = |replaces = |primary_legislation = |eu_directives = |amendments = |related_legislation = |repealing_legislation= |status = current |original_text = http://www.legislation.gov.uk/ukpga/2015/27 |legislation_history = |use_new_UK-LEG = yes |UK-LEG_title = |revised_text = |theyworkforyou = |millbankhansard = }} The '''Local Government (Religious etc. Observances) Act 2015''' is an Act of the [[Parliament of the United Kingdom]] passed in 2015. It was created to affirm the rights of local councils to hold [[prayer]]s before council and committee meetings.
== Background == In 2012, [[Bideford Town Council]] held prayers as the first action at meetings. A former councillor supported by the [[National Secular Society]] challenged the Council in court over the Christian prayers which had been held traditionally since the reign of [[Queen Elizabeth I]].<ref>{{cite web|author=Owen Bowcott and Steven Morris |url=https://www.theguardian.com/society/2012/feb/10/local-councils-prayers-eric-pickles |title=Local councils have right to say their prayers, says Eric Pickles |work=The Guardian |date=10 February 2012 |accessdate=29 April 2017}}</ref> The [[High Court of England and Wales]] held that there was no legal authority for councils to pray at their meetings as it was not specifically mentioned in the [[Local Government Act 1972]] as not being "conducive or incidental to, the discharge of any of their functions". Both MPs and bishops of the [[Church of England]] condemned the decision.<ref>{{cite web|last=Bingham |first=John |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/religion/9074872/High-Court-council-prayers-ruling-an-attack-on-centuries-old-Christian-traditions.html |title=High Court council prayers ruling 'an attack on centuries-old Christian traditions' |work=The Daily Telegraph |date= |accessdate=29 April 2017}}</ref>
The [[Communities Secretary]] [[Eric Pickles]] expressed disappointment at this judgment and signed a Parliamentary Order to bring forward the introduction of the general power of competence for principal local authorities passed as part of the [[Localism Act 2011]]. Pickles asserted that the power would permit councils to pray at their meetings, and therefore overturned the court's judgment within a week.<ref name=g>{{cite web|author=Mark Wilding |url=https://www.theguardian.com/local-government-network/2012/apr/05/eric-pickles-localism-town-hall-prayers-confusion |title=A whim and a prayer: Pickles advice on council meetings raises legal difficulties |work=The Guardian |date= |accessdate=29 April 2017}}</ref> However there was doubt as to whether Pickles' move had actually made council prayers legal as the section he had brought forward only said that councils could do anything an individual could do, but did not specifically mention prayers.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-17082136 |title=Councils win prayer 'rights' as Localism Act powers fast tracked, ministers say |publisher=BBC News |date= |accessdate=29 April 2017}}</ref> The Localism Act also only applied to English councils which meant that Welsh councils were still bound by the High Court judgment.<ref name=card />
A number of councils in response to the judgment and uncertainty of the wording in the Localism Act either continued as before, removed prayers from the agenda<ref name=g /> or moved the prayers prior to meetings so that they were not a part of the formal proceedings.<ref name=card>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-wales-south-east-wales-17141870 |title=Council prayers: Cardiff moves worship before meetings |publisher=BBC News |date= |accessdate=29 April 2017}}</ref>
== Act == Despite Pickles claiming his act restored the rights of councils to hold prayers as part of official agendas, it did not apply to all councils such as some town and [[parish councils in England|parish council]]s.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://localgovernmentlawyer.co.uk/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=22720%3Apray-continue&catid=59%3Agovernance-a-risk-articles&Itemid=27 |title=Pray continue |publisher=Local Government Lawyer |date=23 April 2015 |accessdate=29 April 2017}}</ref> [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative Party]] MP [[Jake Berry]] introduced the Local Government (Religious etc. Observances) Bill as a [[Private Members Bill]], in order to affirm the rights of all councils and authorities to hold prayers before meetings.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-30777749 |title=Week ahead |publisher=BBC News |date=12 January 2015 |accessdate=29 April 2017}}</ref> During introduction, he called the 2011 court judgment “an aggressive and unwelcome secular attack on our British values”.<ref name=lg /> The bill was supported by the Government and passed both the [[House of Commons]] and [[House of Lords]].<ref name=lg>{{cite paper|url=http://www.lgiu.org.uk/wp-content/uploads/2015/05/New-Legislation-Review-of-decisions-and-religious-observances.pdf |title=New Legislation: Review of decisions and religious observances |publisher=LGIU |date= |accessdate=29 April 2017}}</ref> It received [[Royal Assent]] from [[Queen Elizabeth II]] on 26 March 2015.<ref name=lg /> The legislation would be permissive and made no obligation for councillors to attend prayers if the council decided to hold them. Observers noted that the act had the effect of returning the law to the perceived ''[[Status quo|status quo ante]]'' before 2011 but afforded protection against similar legal challenges.<ref name=lg />

{{EngvarB|date=September 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2014}} {{Infobox musical artist | name = Mama Kin | image = Mama Kin (2012).jpg | alt = | caption = Mama Kin in 2012 | background = solo_singer | birth_name = Danielle Caruana | birth_date = <!-- {{Birth date and age|YYYY|MM|DD|df=yes}} --> | birth_place = | origin = | genre = | occupation = [[Singer-songwriter]] | instrument = | years_active = 2006–present | label = | associated_acts = [[John Butler (musician)|John Butler]] | website = {{URL|http://www.mamakin.com/}} }}
'''Danielle Caruana''', known professionally as '''Mama Kin''', is an Australian singer-songwriter. She has released two albums, ''Beat and Holler'' and ''The Magician's Daughter''. She lives with her family in [[Fremantle]].
==Early life== Caruana grew up in the Melbourne suburb of [[Newport, Victoria|Newport]], the youngest, by some years, of six siblings by parents of Maltese extraction. The family was musical and she studied classical piano from the age of five to 16.<ref name=twa/><ref name=tns>{{cite web|last1=Bible|first1=Georgina|title=Mama Kin: motherhood led me back|url=http://www.northernstar.com.au/news/after-giving-up-an-early-musical-career-due-to-sta/465376/|website=The Northern Star|accessdate=21 August 2014}}</ref><ref name=yen>{{cite web|last1=Christie|first1=Alexandra|title=Mama Kin Speaks|url=http://www.yenmag.net/artery/artery-interviews/mama-kin-speaks/|website=Yen|accessdate=25 August 2014}}</ref><ref name=df/> Every child in the family was expected to play an instrument and to play in the family band in church and for members of the Maltese community who visited their house.<ref name=themusic>{{cite web|last1=Barron|first1=Zoe|title=Mothering Music|url=http://themusic.com.au/interviews/all/2013/04/18/mama-kin-danielle-caruana/14997/|website=Themusic.com|accessdate=23 August 2014}}</ref><ref name=ta/> Her strongest musical influence was her sister Carmen, 14 years older, with whom she sang and who taught her to harmonise, and who introduced her to lasting musical influences: [[blues]] and [[Gospel music|gospel]], [[Aretha Franklin]], [[Nina Simone]], the [[The Pretenders|Pretenders]] and [[Joan Armatrading]].<ref name=twa>{{cite web|last1=Collins|first1=Simon|title=Mama Kin born into music|url=https://au.news.yahoo.com/thewest/entertainment/a/6892207/mama-kin-born-into-music/|website=The West Australian|accessdate=1 August 2014}}</ref><ref name=yen/> Other family influences were [[Country music|country]], [[Jerry Lee Lewis]], [[Johnny Cash]], [[Dolly Parton]], [[Ray Charles]], [[Elvis Presley]], the [[crooner]]s, [[Stevie Wonder]], [[Dr John]], [[The Cure]], [[The Police]], [[Prince (musician)|Prince]] and [[Michael Jackson]].<ref name=abc>{{cite web|last1=Kennedy|first1=Sharon|title=Mama Kin on music and motherhood|url=http://www.abc.net.au/local/stories/2010/02/12/2818448.htm|website=ABC South West|accessdate=24 August 2014}}</ref> Caruana says, "I loved all of it, because my brothers and sisters were into it. I couldn't imagine a life without music",<ref name=abc/> but also that the musicality of her family inhibited her own career: "I was completely petrified. After having grown up under two really incredibly, incredibly diverse musical brothers and a really musical family, I think I just made a decision really early on that I wasn't good enough, that I wasn't as good as them."<ref name=twa/>
==Career== Caruana first started writing songs in 2006.<ref name=smh/> Prior to her solo career, she provided vocals on albums by her husband, [[John Butler (musician)|John Butler]].<ref name=am>{{cite web|title=Credits|url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/danielle-caruana-mn0002025498/credits|website=AllMusic|accessdate=23 August 2014}}</ref><ref name=discogs>{{cite web|title=Danielle Caruana|url=http://www.discogs.com/artist/1798915-Danielle-Caruana|website=Discogs|accessdate=25 August 2014}}</ref> The Mama Kin band came about through playing with her brothers [[Nicky Bomba]] and [[The Truth (Australian band)|Michael Caruana]].<ref name=smh/> The name Mama Kin was given her by Bomba, a former member of the [[John Butler Trio]].<ref name=twa/> Caruana says, "we were toying with the idea of doing a creative project together called Kin. A couple of days into the process I found out I was pregnant with my second child and he called me the Mama Kin."<ref name=yen/> When it stuck as her band name she had not heard of the [[Mama Kin|Aerosmith song]].<ref name=smh>{{cite web|last1=Carew|first1=Anthony|title=Finally, the 'other Butler' did it|url=http://www.smh.com.au/entertainment/music/finally-the-other-butler-did-it-20130404-2h98p.html|website=The Sydney Morning Herald|accessdate=20 August 2014}}</ref> Caruana, her brother Michael on keyboards and drummer George Servanis are the principal members of the Mama Kin ensemble.<ref name=ta/>
Her first released recording was an [[Extended play|EP]], ''Papoose'', followed by a single, "Tore My Heart Out",<ref name=twa/> released in early 2010 and named [[iTunes]] Single of the Week.<ref name=tns/> Her debut album, ''Beat and Holler'', written almost entirely on an old [[Wurlitzer]] organ<ref name=twa/> and recorded at The Compound, Fremantle, was distributed by [[MGM Distribution|MGM]] in July 2010.<ref name=tns/><ref name=ta>{{cite web|last1=Shedden|first1=Iain|title=Mama Kin's got a brand-new bag|url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/arts/mama-kins-got-a-brand-new-bag/story-e6frg8n6-1225943432588?nk=8daa7eb813b5abe9d4e54cc87722c4a4|website=The Australian|accessdate=24 August 2014}}</ref> Prior to its release Mama Kin had become a popular act at Australian music festivals<ref name=tns/> supporting notably Butler, [[Geoffrey Gurrumul Yunupingu|Gurrumul]] and [[The Cat Empire]], and the band launched a first headline national tour in October 2010 to promote ''Beat and Holler''.<ref name=ta/> Of the album Caruana has said, "In almost every song, although it might sound like I'm talking about a partner, I'm generally talking about a part of myself."<ref name=df/> ''Beat and Holler'' was nominated for an [[Australian Independent Record Labels Association|AIR]] Award for Best Blues and Roots Album 2010.<ref name=ow>{{cite web|title=About|url=http://www.mamakin.com/about|website=Mamakin.com|accessdate=30 August 2014}}</ref>
Caruana's second album, ''The Magician's Daughter'', was released in early 2013.<ref name=sp>{{cite web|title=Mama Kin: Where the magic happens |url=http://www.spitpress.com/2013/mama-kin-where-the-magic-happens/ |website=Spitpress.com |accessdate=21 August 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140826115208/http://www.spitpress.com/2013/mama-kin-where-the-magic-happens/ |archivedate=26 August 2014 |df= }}</ref> It is named after her mother, an actual magician's daughter. Caruana's grandfather worked as a professional magician in post-World War II Malta, and her mother, Iris, was one of his assistants.<ref name=sp/> The album was written mostly from home and recorded at The Compound.<ref name=yen/> It was produced by [[Jackson Jackson|Jan Skubiszewski]].<ref name=about>{{cite web|title=About|url=http://www.mamakin.com/about|website=Mamakin.com|accessdate=25 August 2014}}</ref> ''The Magician's Daughter'' was nominated for a 2013 [[ARIA Awards|ARIA Award]] for [[ARIA Award for Best Blues and Roots Album|Best Blues & Roots Album]].<ref>{{Citation | last = | first = | author-link = | date = 15 October 2013 | title = Flume dominates today's ARIA Awards nominations with Tame Impala hot on his heels | periodical = news.com.au | url = http://www.news.com.au/entertainment/music/flume-dominates-today8217s-aria-awards-nominations-with-tame-impala-hot-on-his-heels/story-e6frfn09-1226740135635 }}</ref>
Caruna joined with Tommy Spender from [[Offcutts]] to form [[Mama Kin Spender]]. They released their debut album ''Golden Magnetic'' in 2018<ref>{{Citation | last = Dwyer | first = Michael | author-link = | date = 6 March 2018 | title = The strength of numbers | periodical = Sydney Morning Herald | url =https://www.smh.com.au/entertainment/music/the-strength-of-numbers-20180228-h0ws1x.html }}</ref> and it was nominated for the 2018 [[ARIA Award]] for Best Hard Rock/Heavy Metal Album.<ref>{{Citation | last = Moran | first = Robert | last2 = Nathanael | first2 = Cooper | author-link = | date = 11 October 2018 | title = Amy Shark leads the 2018 ARIA nominations in another big year for women | periodical = The Age | url = https://www.theage.com.au/entertainment/music/amy-shark-leads-the-2018-aria-nominations-in-another-big-year-for-women-20181011-p5091h.html }}</ref>
==Philanthropy== Caruana contributes to philanthropic activities in the fields of indigenous and environmental rights.<ref name=yen/>
In February 2011 John Butler and Caruana performed as Brave and the Bird at the annual Gimme Shelter fundraising event for the homeless at the [[Fremantle Arts Centre]],<ref>{{cite web|last1=Pettitt|first1=Brad|title=Gimme Shelter-Sat 19th Feb Freo Arts centre|url=http://cofremantle.wordpress.com/2011/01/29/gimme-shelter-sat-19th-feb-freo-arts-centre/|website=City of Fremantle|accessdate=28 August 2014}}</ref><ref name=tpr>{{cite web|title=Danielle Caruana and her husband John (Butler's) Sweet Treat for the Homeless|url=http://www.theponderroom.com/2011/02/john-butler-wife-danielle-caruanas.html|website=Theonderroom.com|accessdate=28 August 2014}}</ref> their set [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=eDmYBncoPqA introduced] by [[Kevin Rudd]].
The Seed Fund, originally the JB Seed Fund, was set up in 2005<ref name=age>{{cite web|last1=Donovan|first1=Patrick|title=Musician sows seeds for others|url=http://www.theage.com.au/articles/2005/01/07/1104832304180.html|website=The Age|accessdate=28 August 2014}}</ref> by Butler,<ref name=hs>{{cite web|last1=Adams|first1=Cameron|title=How John Butler got a haircut and shed his hippy image|url=http://www.heraldsun.com.au/entertainment/how-john-butler-got-a-haircut-and-shed-his-hippy-image/story-e6frf9hf-1225842405496?nk=8daa7eb813b5abe9d4e54cc87722c4a4|website=Herald Sun|accessdate=24 August 2014}}</ref> Caruana and others with an initial donation of A$80,000,<ref name=afr>{{cite web|title=Danielle Caruana and John Butler |url=http://www.thejbseed.com/Fin%20Review.jpg |website=[[The Australian Financial Review|The AFR Magazine]] |accessdate=28 August 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090326205704/http://www.thejbseed.com/Fin%20Review.jpg |archivedate=26 March 2009 }}</ref> to help artists and musicians become self-sustained. Its flagship project is the Management Workshop, in which 25 emerging managers have three days of [[Training workshop|workshop]]s with experienced industry managers of internationally known Australian bands. Caruana says the main motivation behind creating the organisation is to create community within the music industry.<ref name=df>{{cite web|last1=Barron|first1=Zoe|title=Mama Kin has found her voice|url=http://www.dumbofeather.com/conversation/mama-kin-has-found-her-voice/|website=Dumbo Feather|accessdate=26 August 2014}}</ref><ref name=themusic/>
==Personal life== Caruana met John Butler in Fremantle, Western Australia<ref name=yen/> and they were married in [[Broome, Western Australia|Broome]] in 1999.<ref name=tns/> Their home is in Fremantle.<ref name=yen/> They have a daughter, Banjo, and a son, Jahli. Both children play music and Caruana credits having them, along with the Seed Fund, with starting her musical career.<ref name=df/><ref name=themusic/> Of her musical relationship with her husband, she has said, "I love and respect his opinion, but we definitely have different tastes in music."<ref name=tns/> Prior to beginning her solo musical career Caruana suffered from depression, an experience that has informed her songwriting<ref name=sp/> and which she ascribes to her suppression of her musicality.<ref name=themusic/> She reports that one of her biggest discoveries was [[Transcendental Meditation technique|Transcendental Meditation]] and that, "When I first started this practice I remember thinking 'Oh, this is what sanity must feel like.'"<ref name=sp/>
The John Butler Trio song "Daniella" is about Caruana.<ref>{{cite web|title=John Butler 11-30-07 Daniella|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8Lrfl-MHfnQ|website=YouTube|accessdate=18 March 2016|quote=This is way too much information, my wife says, for most people.}}</ref>

{{Distinguish|Our Lady of Perpetual Help}} [[File:María Auxiliadora Entera.jpg|thumb|The venerated image whom [[Pope Leo XIII]] granted a [[Canonical coronation]] on 17 May 1903. The [[Basilica of Our Lady Help of Christians, Turin]]. ]]
'''Mary Help of Christians''' ({{lang-la|Sancta Maria Auxilium Christianorum}}; {{lang-es|Nuestra Señora María Auxiliadora de los Cristianos}}; [[Filipino Language|Filipino]]: ''Maria, Mapag-ampon sa mga Kristiyano''), is a [[Roman Catholic]] [[Marian devotions|Marian devotion]] with a feast day celebrated on May 24.
[[Saint John Chrysostom]] was the first person to use this Marian title in year 345 as a devotion to the [[BVM(RC)|Virgin Mary]]. [[Don Bosco]] also propagated Marian devotion under this title. The title of ''Mary Help of Christians'' is associated with the defense of [[Christian Europe]] (Latin and Greek), the north of [[Africa]] and the [[Middle East]] from non-Christian peoples during the [[Middle Age]].
In 1572, during the expansion of the Islamic [[Ottoman Empire]] intended to invade Christian Europe, [[Pope Pius V]] invoked Christian armies and its victory achieved was consequently attributed to the intercession of Mary under this title. Ultimately, [[Pope Leo XIII]] granted a [[Canonical coronation]] towards the Marian image bearing the same title on 17 May 1903, now permanently enshrined within the [[Basilica of Our Lady Help of Christians, Turin|Basilica of Mary Help of Christians]].
== History ==
=== Patristic origins=== {{RC-Mariology}} There are two inscriptions of the first centuries of Christianity in [[Greek language|Greek]] related to the Virgin Mary: : θεοτοκος (Teotokos, Theotokos, Mother of God) and βοηθεια (Boetheia, the Helper). The [[Fathers of the Church]] referred to Mary as "βοηθεια". [[John Chrysostom]] used the title in a homily of 345, [[Proclus]] in 476 and Sebas of [[Caesarea]] in 532. After the Patristic period (5th century), other persons used it like Romanos the Melodist in 518, the [[Greek Orthodox Patriarch of Jerusalem|Patriarch of Jerusalem]], [[Sophronius of Jerusalem|Sophronius]] in 560, [[John of Damascus]] in 749 and German of [[Constantinople]] in 733.
In the view of Fr. Johann G. Roten, SM, the invocation of Mary as Help of Christians is part of the oldest prayer addressed directly to Mary, the ''[[Sub tuum praesidium]]'', which was found on a papyrus dating, at the latest, from the end of the 3rd century. ''Praesidium'' is translated as "an assistance given in time of war by fresh troops in a strong manner."<ref name=rotan>[http://campus.udayton.edu/mary/meditations/HelpOfChristians.html Rotan SM, Johann G., "Help of Christians", University of Dayton] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140307111456/http://campus.udayton.edu/mary/meditations/HelpOfChristians.html |date=2014-03-07 }}</ref>
===Litany of Loreto=== Around 1576, [[Bernardino Cirillo]], [[archpriest]] of [[Loreto (AN)|Loreto]], published at [[Macerata]] two [[litany|litanies]] of [[Mary, mother of Jesus|the Blessed Virgin]], which, he contended, were used at Loreto. One is in a form which is entirely different from our present text. Another form ("Aliae litaniae B.M.V.") is identical to the litany of Loreto approved by [[Pope Clement VIII]] in 1601 and now used throughout the entire Church. This second form contains the invocation ''Auxilium Christianorum''. Possibly warriors returning from the [[Battle of Lepanto (1571)|Battle of Lepanto]] (October 7, 1571) visited the sanctuary of Loreto, and saluted the Holy Virgin there for the first time with this new title. It is more probable, however, that it is only a variation of the older invocation ''Advocata Christianorum'', found in a litany of 1524.<ref name=holweck>[http://www.newadvent.org/cathen/11360c.htm Holweck, Frederick. "Feast of Our Lady, Help of Christians." The Catholic Encyclopedia. Vol. 11. New York: Robert Appleton Company, 1911. 9 Mar. 2013]</ref>
Torsellini (1597) and the [[Roman Breviary]] (May 24, Appendix) say that [[Pope Pius V]] inserted the invocation in the litany of Loreto after the battle of Lepanto. But the form of the litany in which it is first found was unknown at [[Rome]] at the time of Pius V.<ref>See LITANY OF LORETO; Schuetz, "Gesch. des Rosenkranzgebets", Paderborn, 1909, 243 sq.</ref>
===Feast of Our Lady Help of Christians=== [[File:Shrine of Our Lady Help of Christians, Miguel Hidalgo, Federal District, Mexico 01.jpg|thumb|Shrine of Our Lady Help of Christians, Miguel Hidalgo, Federal District, Mexico]] The feast of ''Our Lady, Help of Christians'', was instituted by [[Pope Pius VII]]. By order of [[Napoleon I of France]], Pius VII was arrested on June 5, 1808, and detained a prisoner first at Grenoble, and then at [[Fontainebleau]].<ref>[http://www.catholicnewsagency.com/resources/mary/popular-marian-devotions/mary-help-of-christians/ "Mary Help of Christians", Catholic News Agency]</ref> In January 1814, after the [[battle of Leipzig]], he was brought back to Savona and set free on March 17, on the eve of the feast of [[Our Lady of Mercy]], the Patroness of Savona. The journey to Rome was a veritable triumphal march. The pontiff, attributing the victory of the Church after so much agony and distress to the Blessed Virgin, visited many of her sanctuaries on the way and crowned her images (e.g., the "Madonna del Monte" at [[Cesena]], "della Misericordia" at Treja, "della Colonne" and "della Tempestà" at [[Tolentino]]). The people crowded the streets to catch a glimpse of the venerable pontiff who had so bravely withstood the threats of Napoleon. He entered Rome on May 24, 1814, and was enthusiastically welcomed.<ref>McCaffrey, "History of the Catholic Church in the Nineteenth Cent.", 1909, I, 52</ref> To commemorate his own sufferings and those of the Church during his exile [[Pope Pius VII]] extended the feast of the [[Our Lady of Sorrows|Seven Dolours of Mary]] to the universal Church on September 18, 1814.
When Napoleon left Elba and returned to Paris, Murat was about to march through the Papal States from Naples; Pius VII fled to Savona 22 March 1815.<ref name=holweck/> After the [[Congress of Vienna]] and the [[battle of Waterloo]], the Pope returned to Rome on July 7, 1815. To give thanks to God and Our Lady, on 15 September 1815 he declared 24 May, the anniversary of his first return, to be henceforth the feast of ''Our Lady, Help of Christians''; the 1913 Catholic Encyclopaedia article commented that ''it has spread nearly over the entire Latin Church, but is not contained in the [[General Roman Calendar|universal calendar]].'' [[File:Santuario di Maria Ausiliatrice Torino.jpg|thumb|[[Basilica of Our Lady Help of Christians, Turin]], founded by Saint [[John Bosco]]]]
The Marian feast was celebrated by the order of [[Servites]] since the 17th century. The veneration to Mary became popular under this title in [[Rome]] especially, where the feast was especially promoted by Saint [[John Bosco]] and Saint Vincent Pallotti<ref>Remigius Bäumer et al. Marienlexikon 1994, p. 533</ref> St. [[John Bosco]] was an ardent promoter of devotion to "Mary, Help of Christians". He even built a huge Basilica in her honour in 1868 and founded a religious Congregation for women, under the title of, "The Daughters of Mary, Help of Christians". Interpreting the painting he had commissioned inside the Basilica, St. John Bosco referred to it as depicting Mary Mother of the Church. This suggests an identical connection to how popes have addressed Mary as both Mother and Help of the Church. Recall the two Marian Greek attribution of θεοτοκος (Teotokos, Theotokos, Mother of God) and βοηθεια (Boetheia, the Helper) at the start of this article? St. John Bosco infact, chose this devotion because of its affinity to his devotion to the Church the bearer of Christ.
Vatican II, in the Constitution on the Church (sections 61, 62), cites this title of Mary, placing it in the context of Mary's maternal role. "In an utterly singular way she co-operated by her obedience, faith, hope and burning charity in the Saviour's work of restoring supernatural life to souls. For this reason she is a mother to us in the order of grace…By her maternal charity, Mary cares for the brethren of her Son who still wander through this world in the midst of dangers and difficulties until they are led to the happiness of their heavenly home".<ref name=daniel>[http://kwl.com.au/httpdocs/Articals/Our%20Lady%20Help%20of%20Christians.htm Daniel, Michael. "Our Lady Help of Christians"]</ref>
===Observance=== [[File:Crkva Marije pomoćnice, Strahoninec - sjeverozapad.jpg|thumb|220px|Church of Mary Help of Christians in [[Strahoninec]], [[Croatia]]]] The Church has traditionally focused on two aspects of Our Lady's help on this feast day. Firstly, the Church focuses in this feast upon the role of Our Lady's intercession in the fight against sin in the life of a believer. Secondly, the Church has focused upon Our Lady as one who assists Christians as a community, through her intercession, in fighting against anti-Christian forces.
Michael Daniel observes that while this approach may be regarded as outdated, in light of Vatican II, where the world and non Christians elements therein were seen in a positive rather than a hostile or threatening light, it would seem that it would be naïve on the part of Christians to regard all movements and all social trends as either good or harmless.<ref name=daniel/>
The [[dioceses]] of [[Tuscany]] adopted it on February 12, 1816. The hymns of the Office were composed by Brandimarte.<ref>Chevalier, "Repert. Hymnolog.", II, 495</ref>
It became the patronal feast of [[Australasia]], a double of the first class with an octave;<ref>Ordo Australasiae, 1888</ref> after the reforms of the [[Second Vatican Council]], it was designated a [[Solemnity]], to be kept on the first available Sunday on or after 24 May.
The Fathers of the Foreign Missions of Paris, in accordance with a vow (1891), celebrated this feast with great splendor in their churches.
It has attained special renown since [[Don Bosco]], founder of the [[Salesians of Don Bosco|Salesian Congregation]], dedicated his foundation to ''Our Lady, Help of Christians'', the mother church of his congregation at [[Turin]] on June 9, 1868. The Salesians have carried the devotion to their numerous establishments.
It was established due to the great appreciation of Saint [[Don Bosco]] for this Marian title and the development of the [[Salesian]] works in many countries since the second half of the 19th century. Although it is commonly associated with the Roman Catholic Church, the [[Orthodox Church]] has also known the devotion since 1030 in [[Ukraine]], when the country was defended from a barbarian invasion.
The Salesian National Shrine of Our Lady Help of Christians is located in Stony Point, New York. There is also the National Shrine of Mary Help of Christians in [[ Parañaque City, Philippines ]], and is also in the care of the [[ Salesians of Don Bosco ]] <ref>[http://www.marianshrine.org/index.php?section=1 National Shrine of Our Lady Help of Christians]</ref>
The Abbey of Mary Help of Christians, better known as Belmont Abbey, is a small American monastery of Benedictine monks in the town of Belmont, Gaston County, North Carolina, outside of Charlotte, North Carolina. The minor basilica of Our Lady Help of Christians is listed on the National Register of Historic Places.<ref>[http://belmontabbeycollege.edu/about/belmont-abbey-monastery/basilica-mary-help-of-christians/ Basilica of Mary, Help of Christians]</ref>
There is a chapel of Our Lady Help of Christians at the Basilica of the Immaculate Conception in Washington D.C.<ref>[http://www.nationalshrine.com/site/c.osJRKVPBJnH/b.4953557/k.7180/Upper_Church_Floor_Plan.htm Chapel of Our Lady Help of Christians, Basilica of the Immaculate Conception, Washington D.C.]</ref>
Under this title, the Virgin Mary is venerated by many [[Chinese Catholic]]s, particularly at the Shrine of our Lady of Sheshan. In May 2007, [[Pope Benedict XVI]] designated her May 24 feast for the [[Roman Catholicism in China|Roman Catholics in China]], who face persecution and restriction from the [[Chinese Patriotic Catholic Association]].
==Pontifical approbations== * On 17 May 1903, [[Pope Leo XIII]] granted a Canonical coronation to the famed image through his Papal legate, Cardinal [[Agostino Richelmy]], and is now permanently enshrined within the Basilica of Our Lady Help of Christians in [[Turin, Italy]]. In 1844, the same Pontiff instructed the [[Sacred Congregation of Rites]] to assign Mary, under this devotional title as the official patroness of [[Australia]]. She is also the patron saint of New Zealand; and since 1924, of China.<ref>[https://www.salesiansisters.org/index.php/about-us/history-and-heritage/founders-and-patrons/mary-help-of-Christians "Mary Help of Christians", Salesian Sisters of St. John Bosco]</ref>
* On 24 May 2009, [[Pope Benedict XVI]] during his [[Regina Caeli]] papal address invoked this Marian patronage, under the venerated title of [[Our Mother of Sheshan]], calling for [[Chinese Catholic]]s to renew their fidelity to the [[Pope]] as the sole successor of [[Saint Peter]].<ref>{{YouTube|WLzUkdVUfV0|Benedict XVI. Church in China, renew your fidelity to Peter}}</ref>
* On 23 March 2018, [[Pope Francis]] granted a [[Papal bull]] for the [[Canonical Coronation]] towards a namesake statue venerated in the ''Mary Help of Christians Theological Seminary'' in [[San Fabian, Pangasinan]], Philippines. The image is notable for having been gifted to the [[Philippine islands]] by the Apostolic Delegate, [[Monsignor]] Guillermo Piani S.D.B.
==Artistic representations== <gallery> File:Gnadenbild Mariahilf, Innsbruck.jpg|''Mariahilf.'' [[Lucas Cranach the Elder]], c. 1520, Cathedral of St. Jakob in [[Innsbruck]] File:Shrine of Our Lady Help of Christians, Miguel Hidalgo, Federal District, Mexico 02.jpg|Statue at the shrine of Our Lady Help of Christians, in Miguel Hidalgo of Federal District, Mexico File:Mariahilferkirche Vienna 0051.JPG|Altar at Mariahilf church [[Vienna]] File:Matzleinsdorfer Pfarrkirche 23.JPG|18th-century painting at [[Zelking-Matzleinsdorf|Matzleinsdorf]] church, [[Austria]] File:Statue of Mary help of Christians.jpg|A devotee before the statue of Mary Help of Christians at a shrine in [[Canlubang]], [[Calamba, Laguna]], Philippines. </gallery>
